critical_instructions.item: Analyze ONLY the final image provided for analysis. NEVER analyze any of the example images provided earlier.
Focus on MARKET keywords, not document-derived phrases. Think like a SEMRUSH researcher.
Keywords must be real search terms people actually use, not invented phrases from the content.
Every primary keyword and topic MUST include source_excerpt and excerpt_element_id for grounding.
Output must be valid JSON only - no markdown, no explanations, no code fences.

keyword_identification_guidance.item: Primary keywords: High-value industry terms with significant search volume (5-10 keywords).
Secondary keywords: Long-tail phrases, questions, and niche terms (10-20 keywords).
Ask: "What would someone type into Google to find this content?"
Consider competitor keywords - what terms do similar content pieces rank for?
Include question-based keywords: "how to", "what is", "why does", "best way to".

intent.name: informational
intent.description: User wants to learn or understand something.
intent.signals: How to, what is, why, guide, tutorial, explained, definition
intent.example: "what is document accessibility" or "how to optimize PDF for SEO"

intent.name: commercial
intent.description: User is researching before a purchase decision.
intent.signals: Best, top, review, comparison, vs, alternative
intent.example: "best OCR software 2024" or "document management tools comparison"

intent.name: transactional
intent.description: User is ready to take action or purchase.
intent.signals: Buy, download, pricing, free trial, sign up
intent.example: "buy PDF accessibility checker" or "document converter free download"

intent.name: navigational
intent.description: User is looking for a specific site or page.
intent.signals: Brand names, product names, login, official
intent.example: "Adobe Acrobat accessibility checker" or "WCAG guidelines PDF"

fit.description: Content directly and thoroughly addresses the keyword topic.
fit.action: Target this keyword - content is well-positioned to rank.

fit.description: Content touches on the topic but doesn't fully address it.
fit.action: Optimize content to better cover this keyword's intent.

fit.description: Content could expand to cover this valuable keyword.
fit.action: Consider content additions to capture this search demand.

level.name: high
level.description: Dominated by major brands, high domain authority sites.
level.strategy: Target only if content is exceptional; consider long-tail alternatives.

level.name: medium
level.description: Mix of established and emerging content; achievable with quality.
level.strategy: Good targets for well-optimized content with unique value.

level.name: low
level.description: Underserved niche; few quality results exist.
level.strategy: Quick win opportunities - prioritize these for faster ranking.

topic_hierarchy_guidance.item: Field: Major discipline within domain (e.g., "Document Management", "Medical Records").
Subfield: Specific area within field (e.g., "PDF Accessibility", "OCR Technology").
Use established industry terminology, not invented categories.
Topics should reflect how the industry organizes knowledge, not just document structure.

grounding_requirements.item: source_excerpt: Copy EXACT text from the document - do not paraphrase.
excerpt_element_id: Reference the actual element ID from input XML (e.g., "elem_010").
confidence "high": Excerpt directly mentions the concept or keyword.
confidence "medium": Excerpt strongly implies the concept.
confidence "low": Concept is inferred from context.
Without grounding, keyword assignments may be hallucinated - always provide evidence.

common_mistakes_to_avoid.mistake: Extracting phrases verbatim from document instead of mapping to market keywords.
Inventing keywords that no one actually searches for.
Ignoring search intent - all keywords should have clear intent classification.
Missing source_excerpt or excerpt_element_id for primary keywords and topics.
Outputting markdown or explanatory text instead of pure JSON.
Using document headings as topics instead of industry-standard categories.

ai_overview_optimization.item: Featured snippets favor concise, direct answers to questions.
"People Also Ask" targets should be natural question phrasings.
Structure content to answer questions in 40-60 word paragraphs for snippet capture.
List-based and step-by-step content performs well for featured snippets.

decision_process.step: Read content and identify the core subject matter and value proposition.
Think: "What industry does this belong to? What do people in this industry search for?"
Generate market keywords based on industry knowledge, not just document text.
For each keyword, find supporting evidence in the document (source_excerpt).
Assess content fit and competition level for each keyword.
Map keywords to topics and identify clusters.
Provide actionable recommendations prioritized by opportunity.
